query: What are the responsibilities of the management body regarding ICT governance?
answer:
- Ensure an adequate internal governance and internal control framework for ICT and security risks, and set clear roles and responsibilities for ICT functions, information security risk management and business continuity (including for the management body and its committees) [CSSF 3.2.1 / 2].

- Ensure sufficient quantity, skills and training of staff to support ICT operations and ICT/security risk management, ensure an appropriate budget, and require annual (or more frequent if needed) ICT/security training for all staff, including key function holders [CSSF 3.2.1 / 3].

- Have overall accountability for setting, approving and overseeing the implementation of the institution’s ICT strategy as part of its business strategy, and for establishing an effective ICT and security risk management framework [CSSF 3.2.1 / 4].

- Ensure a control function is assigned, independent from ICT operations, directly accountable to the management body to monitor and control adherence to the ICT and security risk management framework (and ensure that internal audit can independently review ICT activities) [CSSF 3.3.1 / 11].

- Define, approve, review (at least annually) and be reported to on the ICT and security risk management framework, including risk appetite, identification, mitigation, monitoring, incident reporting and assessment after major changes or incidents [CSSF 3.3.1 / 13; CSSF 3.3.1 / 14].

- Establish and oversee programme/project governance for ICT projects (roles, responsibilities, accountability), ensure project risks and interdependencies are monitored and included in the risk management framework, and receive regular or ad hoc reports on project establishment, progress and risks [CSSF 3.6.1 / 61-63; CSSF 3.6.1 / 62; CSSF 3.6.1 / 66].

- Bear ultimate responsibility for managing ICT risk; put in place policies ensuring availability, authenticity, integrity and confidentiality of data; set clear roles for all ICT-related functions and governance to ensure timely coordination among them [DORA Article 5 / 2(a)-(c)].

- Bear overall responsibility for setting and approving the digital operational resilience strategy, including determining ICT risk tolerance; approve, oversee and periodically review ICT business continuity policies and ICT response and recovery plans; and approve and periodically review ICT internal audit plans and material modifications [DORA Article 5 / 2(d)-(f)].

- Allocate and periodically review an appropriate budget for digital operational resilience needs (including security awareness programmes, training and ICT skills); approve and periodically review policy on use of ICT third‑party service providers; and establish reporting channels to be informed of arrangements, planned material changes, impacts and major ICT-related incidents [DORA Article 5 / 2(g)-(i)].

- Ensure at least major ICT-related incidents are reported to senior management and that the management body is informed of at least major ICT-related incidents, with explanations of impact, response and additional controls [DORA Article 17 / 3(e)].

- Actively keep up to date with sufficient knowledge and skills to understand and assess ICT risk, including by taking regular, commensurate training [DORA Article 5 / 4].
